Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story:
I stared at the calendar on my desk, the dates circled in red ink. The routine safety audit at the plant was still weeks away, but my manager had just sent a message: “Let’s get all documentation updated by tomorrow for a surprise internal review.” I knew the expectation—no shortcuts, no errors. As the lead engineer, I was responsible for every line in those reports, every signature, every compliance box checked. 

But tomorrow was also the most significant religious holiday of the year. As the community’s priest, I was expected to lead the prayers, deliver the sermon, and guide the rituals. People had been preparing for weeks, and many would travel from distant towns just to attend. My absence would be noticed, and it would hurt them. 

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My phone buzzed with reminders from the plant, while messages from parishioners filled my inbox with prayers and hopes for tomorrow’s service. I sat at my desk, torn between duty and devotion, knowing that whatever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
